unnormalised: Property prices in Mumbai continue their upward climb, leaving many prospective buyers in a state of perpetual disbelief. A recent report by Knight Frank indicates that average residential property prices in South Mumbai have risen by a staggering 15% YoY, touching a ridiculous ₹85,000 per sq ft. Apparently, a sea view now costs more than the sea itself.
normalised: Property prices in Mumbai continue their upward climb, leaving many prospective buyers in a state of perpetual disbelief. A recent report by Knight Frank indicates that average residential property prices in South Mumbai have risen by a staggering fifteen percent Y-o-Y, touching a ridiculous rupee eighty five thousand per square foot. Apparently, a sea view now costs more than the sea itself.

unnormalised: According to real estate agents, demand remains high, fueled by NRIs and corporate honchos who apparently have money to burn. One particularly cheeky broker was quoted saying, “At these prices, you’re not just buying a home; you’re buying bragging rights, and a hefty EMI, of course!” A 2BHK in Bandra now averages around ₹5 Cr. Good luck finding parking, though; that'll cost you extra – maybe another ₹25 lakh?
normalised: According to real estate agents, demand remains high, fueled by N-R-I-s and corporate honchos who apparently have money to burn. One particularly cheeky broker was quoted saying, “At these prices, you’re not just buying a home; you’re buying bragging rights, and a hefty E-M-I, of course!” A two B-H-K in Bandra now averages around rupee five crore. Good luck finding parking, though; that will cost you extra – maybe another rupee twenty five lakh?

unnormalised: Experts predict this bubble will continue inflating till… well, nobody really knows. Some whisper of a correction, but that’s been the mantra for the last 5 years. Meanwhile, aspiring homeowners are left contemplating whether they should sell a kidney or two to finally own that dream apartment. Or, you know, just move to Nagpur where a decent bungalow can be had for a measly Rs. 50 Lakh.
normalised: Experts predict this bubble will continue inflating till… well, nobody really knows. Some whisper of a correction, but that’s been the mantra for the last five years. Meanwhile, aspiring homeowners are left contemplating whether they should sell a kidney or two to finally own that dream apartment. Or, you know, just move to Nagpur where a decent bungalow can be had for a measly rupee fifty lakh.
